title: Why Gwyneth Paltrow spoke out about Harvey Weinstein
text:
From Harper's BAZAAR

Gwyneth Paltrow has opened up about her part in the groundbreaking New York Times investigation of Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein, which helped catapult the #MeToo movement into the mainstream, during an interview with NBC's Savannah Guthrie.

This was Paltrow's first live television interview since the Times reporters who broke the Weinstein scandal released She Said, a book chronicling the investigation that eventually led to his downfall.

"I was really scared," the actress said. "I think society had shown us only basically examples where women coming forward ended up not being advantageous for the woman, but I really felt like it was time."

In 2017, the actress told the Times that the now-maligned producer sexually harassed her after hiring her for the lead in Emma, a role that eventually propelled her fledgling career into stardom.

She allegedly met Weinstein at a hotel for a work meeting when he began to touch her and suggested they move into the bedroom for massages. She said she rejected him.



Her allegations (along with those of other notables who publicly spoke to the Times, such as Angelina Jolie) revealed a repeated pattern of sexual abuse at the hands of one of Hollywood's biggest producers, although Weinstein has denied the accusations.

During the interview, Guthrie noted that She Said authors Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey credited Paltrow for being a major asset to their investigation. "They said, 'Gwyneth Paltrow, behind the scenes, helped us move this piece when we were really stuck,'" Guthrie told the actress.

Photo credit: Patrick McMullan - Getty Images More

Paltrow also told Guthrie that her daughter played a part in her decision to speak out.

"I think also having a teenage daughter that's the love of my life and worrying about her going into the workplace, and feeling like if there was ever a chance that there could be a cultural shift on this stuff, I wanted to participate in," she said. "I never could have imagined that collectively a shift this seismic would happen, but I feel proud that I have a small part in it.”

At the time of Paltrow's initial allegations, spokesman for Weinstein told the Times, "Any allegations of non-consensual sex are unequivocally denied by Mr. Weinstein. Mr. Weinstein has further confirmed that there were never any acts of retaliation against any women for refusing his advances. He will not be available for further comments, as he is taking the time to focus on his family, on getting counselling and rebuilding his life."
